section1.title: Understanding Bond Investments
section1.p1: Bonds are debt securities that represent loans made by investors to governments or corporations. When you buy a bond, you're essentially lending money to the issuer in exchange for periodic interest payments and the return of your principal at maturity.
section1.p2: Bonds are considered safer investments compared to stocks because they provide predictable income and have a higher claim on assets in case of bankruptcy. They play a crucial role in diversified investment portfolios and are essential for long-term wealth building.
list: Face Value: The principal amount repaid at maturity
Coupon Rate: The annual interest rate paid to bondholders
Maturity Date: When the bond expires and principal is repaid
Yield to Maturity: Total return if held until maturity

section2.title: Types of Bonds Available in India

government.title: Government Bonds
government.description: Securities issued by the central or state governments, considered the safest bond investments with government backing.

corporate.title: Corporate Bonds
corporate.description: Bonds issued by companies to raise capital for business operations, offering higher yields but with credit risk.

municipal.title: Municipal Bonds
municipal.description: Bonds issued by local governments for public projects, often providing tax benefits to investors.

psu.title: PSU Bonds
psu.description: Bonds issued by Public Sector Undertakings, backed by government ownership and strong fundamentals.

inflation_linked.title: Inflation-Indexed Bonds
inflation_linked.description: Bonds where principal and interest payments are adjusted for inflation, protecting purchasing power.

tax_free.title: Tax-Free Bonds
tax_free.description: Bonds issued by government agencies where interest income is exempt from income tax.

section3.title: RBI's Role in Bond Markets
section3.p1: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) plays a crucial role in the Indian bond market by regulating monetary policy, managing government debt issuance, and maintaining market liquidity.
section3.p2: Key functions of RBI in bond markets include:
list: Setting interest rates that influence bond yields across the market
Managing the issuance and trading of government securities
Regulating market participants and ensuring fair trading practices
Providing liquidity support through various monetary policy tools
Maintaining market stability through intervention when necessary

spotTheBondRisk.title: Identify Bond Investment Risks
spotTheBondRisk.scenario1: A friend recommends a corporate bond offering 15% annual returns. Which is the biggest concern?

options1.0: The company operates in a stable industry
options1.1: The unusually high return suggests significant credit risk
options1.2: The bond has a 5-year maturity period

spotTheBondRisk.answer1: The unusually high return suggests significant credit risk
spotTheBondRisk.scenario2: You're considering a government bond vs. a fixed deposit. Which factor is most important?

options2.0: Government bonds are traded on exchanges providing liquidity
options2.1: Fixed deposits have DICGC insurance coverage
options2.2: Both options should be evaluated based on your risk profile and investment horizon

spotTheBondRisk.answer2: Both options should be evaluated based on your risk profile and investment horizon
spotTheBondRisk.scenario3: An agent offers you a 'government-guaranteed' bond with 12% returns through a mobile app. What's concerning?

options3.0: Legitimate government bonds don't offer such high returns
options3.1: The mobile app platform seems convenient

spotTheBondRisk.answer3: Legitimate government bonds don't offer such high returns
